Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open, spreadsheets and project timelines glowing on the screen. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Don’t forget to buy the Nintendo for Jamie.” I’d promised my son weeks ago, after his good grades, that I’d get him the game console he’d been dreaming about. He’d been counting down the days, his excitement growing with every mention. But as I stared at the numbers on my screen, my mind raced with another worry. My manager was waiting for my effort estimates for the new client project. The contract—and a significant chunk of our team’s revenue—depended on my calculations. If I got it wrong, the project could spiral out of control, risking not just my reputation but the financial stability I worked so hard to provide for my family. I could hear Jamie in the next room, humming with anticipation, while my inbox pinged with another “urgent” from my boss. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: be the reliable parent, keep my promise, or be the dependable engineer, secure our future. I stared at the screen, torn, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
